awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: New Perspectives on Special Methods for Graph Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Classical algorithms for many important graph primitives were designed at a time when the conventional notion of efficiency was polynomial running time.  However, many of today's applications involve graphs consisting of millions, or even billions, of nodes. On these massive inputs, practical algorithms must run in time that is as close to linear as possible in the size of the input.

The spectral approach to designing graph algorithms views the instance graph as a matrix and makes use of the algebraic properties of the corresponding linear operator. Recently, research in this area has led to the design of faster spectral algorithms for many essential graph problems, such as electrical flow, maximum flow and graph partitioning in undirected graphs.  The goal of this project is to develop a novel algorithmic approach by combining spectral methods and the idea of regularization from optimization.  Regularization is a mechanism for modifying a given optimization problem to make it more amenable to known algorithms without changing its salient characteristics. Surprisingly, many of the recent breakthroughs in the design of fast spectral algorithms can be viewed as applying different types of regularization. This research aims to exploit this interpretation to design algorithms that are faster, simpler to analyze and easier to implement. Another aim of this research is to integrate different perspectives on regularization from Machine Learning, Statistics and Convex Optimization, to create new bridges between these fields and the design of algorithms.

Due to the practical importance of the graph problems under consideration, the work will also focus on empirically evaluating the algorithms designed.  These evaluations will be disseminated to the relevant audiences to maximize the impact of the award. Moreover, because this project aims to develop new fundamental techniques in the design of algorithms, a particular effort will be devoted to incorporating material from this research into the PI's teaching activity and to preparing educational material for the public.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop a novel algorithmic framework for the efficient solution of graph problems by eschewing classical combinatorial techniques and relying instead on tools from continuous optimization.  In particular, the projected focused on leveraging spectral methods, which allow us to represent graphs by linear operators, i.e., matrices, and the optimization technique of smoothing (aka regularization), which allows us to modify possibly complex and unstable problems (such as combinatorial problems) into approximate versions that are amenable to first-order iterative methods, such as gradient descent. The PI's approach is novel as previous breakthrough works in this area had focused on deploying the right spectral formulations for iterative methods to work on, without exploring the power of smoothing.

The PI was successful in carrying out the proposed research. In particular, the PI clarified the role of regularization in the problem of graph sparsification, i.e., the task of taking a graph G and constructing a weighted subgraph G' that has much fewer edges but spectrally approximates G. The PI has shown that different sampling techniques, both oblivious and adaptive, correspond to different regularizations of the problem and that certain regularizations are amenable to faster implementations. Through these techniques, the PI and student Allen-Zhu gave the fastest known algorithm for constructing sparsifiers that have a linear number of edges. The techniques of this paper, which appeared in STOC'15, were later used to improve the PI's results and obtain nearly-linear-time algorithms for this problem, by Lee and Sun.

In a different direction, the PI exploited his understanding of regularization to get new insights on the concept of acceleration in first-order optimization. Acceleration encompasses a number of methods that speed up many gradient descent algorithms for smooth functions. Examples of accelerated methods include both general methods like Nesterov's accelerated gradient methods, Nemirovski's mirror-prox, Polyak heavy-ball method and specific instantiations like Chebishev's method for solving PSD linear systems of equations. While acceleration has been introduced as a general methods since the 1980s, the mathematical foundations of this techniques were somewhat mysterious and prevented further generalizations of this important concept. With co-author Allen-Zhu, the PI leveraged his new interpretation of accelerated methods to give a number of breakthrough results on the solution of large-scale resource allocation linear programs, an important class of mathematical programs that has many logistical applications. These results were published in SODA, STOC and are currently under submission at top optimization journals. This work allowed the PI to build bridges and collaborations with the continuous optimization community. As a result, in fall 2017, the PI will be one of the main organizers of a large semester program at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing at UC Berkeley, entitled "Bridging Discrete and Continuous Optimization".

The project has had an impact beyond the research work outlined above. The development of novel algorithms for resource allocations LPs has drawn the attention of many practitioners: the PI and co-authors have presented their work in a variety of applied contexts, including industry. The project has contributed to the training of student Zeyuan Allen-Zhu, who worked closely with the PI while the PI was an Applied Instructor at MIT, and is now a postdoctoral fellow at Princeton and at the Institute of Advanced Studies. Finally, the project led to the wide dissemination of a manuscript explaining the PI and co-authors' new interpretation of accelerated methods. This manuscript received broad attention in both the TCS and Optimization community and has inspired a number of collaborations across these disciplines. The manuscript was recently accepted for presentation at the conference Innovations in Theoretical Computer Science 2017.
